messageBody:
On Tuesday 29 June 2004 08:46 pm, Martijn Dashorst wrote:
> I was thinking of overriding runBare() in which I allocate the driver
> before calling super.runBare(), and in a finally block, I dereference
> the driver:
>
> public void runBare() throws Throwable {
> try {
> tester = new WebTester();
> super.runBare();
> } finally {
> tester = null;
> }
> }
>
> This is rather risky, for I have no guarantee that runBare() is called
> in each environment (ant, Eclipse, IntelliJ, etc).

I think you can depend upon this.  It isn't a plugin responsibility as
you imply here, it's the JUnit framework that calls runBare().  As I
recall, and I could certainly be wrong, there is much more code to
override/implement if you wish to hook in above the runBare().  I have
yet to hear of an IDE plugin that doesn't call runBare().

DTSTTCPW and YAGNI are good principles to apply here.  Depend on
runBare() being called until such time that you _absolutely_ know that
it isn't, then you can change the code to adapt to that scenario.

Just my $0.02.
